qas.question: What case is in regards to whether prayers at town meetings must allow various faiths?

context: In what will be the case is <a0_0><b5_0>Town of Greece v. Galloway<b5_0/><a0_0/>, 12-696, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a case regarding whether prayers at town meetings, which are allowed, must allow various faiths to lead prayer, or whether the prayers can be predominately Christian. On <a1_0><b6_0>May 5, 2014<b6_0/><a1_0/>, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled <a2_0><b7_0>5-4<b7_0/><a2_0/> in favor of the <a3_0><b8_0>Town of Greece<b8_0/><a3_0/> by holding that the U.S. Constitution not only allows for prayer at government meetings, but also for <a4_0><b9_0>sectarian prayers<b9_0/><a4_0/> like predominately Christian prayers.
